Nu!RehaVR: virtual reality in neuro tele-rehabilitation of patients with traumatic brain injury and stroke

Nu!RehaVR: virtual reality in neuro tele-rehabilitation of patients with traumatic brain injury and stroke

  • Osvaldo Gervasi1,
  • Riccardo Magni2 &
  • Mauro Zampolini3 

Virtual Reality volume 14, pages131–141(2010)Cite this article

  • 553 Accesses

  • 18 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The availability of virtual environments on the Web is fostering new applications of virtual reality in several fields, including some therapeutical applications. We present an application of virtual reality applied to the tele-rehabilitation of patients with traumatic brain injury and stroke. Our system, based on X3D and Ajax3D technologies, enhances the possibility of making tele-rehabilitation exercises aimed at the recovery of the neurological disease. The system, called Nu!RehaVR, has been designed to integrate the activity carried out on a tele-rehabilitation system, Nu!Reha (Nu!Reha is a trademark of Pragma Engineering srl. See http://www.nureha.eu) desk, with the activities performed in the virtual worlds, through some rehabilitation exercises in contexts incompatible with the patients’ impairments (not able to move or forced in static positions because of therapies, etc.). The architecture of Nu!RehaVR and the environments associated to two exercises, “Utilising an elevator to reach a given floor” and “Crossing a road using a traffic light”, are illustrated. These exercises can be considered as prototypes of a series of tele-rehabilitation exercises which help to stimulate the patients performing actions in relatively dangerous scenarios. The system is designed to allow the remote monitoring and assessment of the patient’s activities by the medical staff at the hospital using the communication facilities of the tele-rehabilitation system.

Introduction

In recent years, the development of hardware technologies has made available an impressive computational capability, particularly for graphics and virtual reality applications, making it possible to deliver interactive and immersive virtual worlds via the Web, fostering new scenarios for the usage of the virtual reality.

In the present paper, we describe the Nu!RehaVR system, in which some virtual worlds have been implemented to enable patients to stimulate their neurological system and increase their cognitive capabilities, integrating the activity performed on the Nu!Reha (Nu!Reha is a trademark of Pragma Engineering srl. See http://www.nureha.eu) desk, with that performed in the virtual environment.

The Nu!RehaVR system is applied to patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) and stroke: both need a long-term post-acute rehabilitation, stimulating various capacities and abilities in order to recover autonomy and quality of life. Depending on the clinical protocol adopted, the patients are stimulated to execute functions and activities with an increasing level of complexity and difficulty.

The main issues addressed with the practices are: personal autonomy, communication and relationships, planning, motivation, self-awareness, emotional control.

The final aim of every rehabilitation programme is to return the person to her/his family and life context at the maximum of the achievable potential. For this reason, the repetition and the variety of the proposed exercises play an important role. The contextual approach is underlining the benefit coming from a complete and realistic task execution with respect to exercises training just one function at a time. The Nu!Reha desk presents to the patient a realistic scenario where she/he is asked to interact in a real life context. The Nu!RehaVR extends the frontiers of real life simulations adding new scenarios that could not be addressed in real environments in a safe and controlled mode. This is particularly relevant in case of long stay in hospital of patients: in such case, in fact, the virtual reality plays a unique role to facilitate the rehabilitation of the patients.

Nu!RehaVR presents the following main advantages: the chance to organise a list of repeat exercises; enables the patient self management during exercise execution; performs the data recording for each exercise and each session; provides to the medical doctor the chance to prepare a scenario calibrating its complexity, trimming stimula, changing environment feedbacks, allowing the remote management of the system in a tele-rehabilitation scheme. This last point allows the continuation of rehabilitative programmes, even outside the hospital and far from the therapist physical intervention, providing the chance to take benefit from the intensive training in out-patient condition and emphasising the advantages of the tele-rehabilitation programme.

The paper is structured as follows. In Sect. 2, a review of the existing research related to neuro tele-rehabilitation and the adoption of virtual reality techniques is presented.

In Sect. 3, the Nu!Reha system is illustrated. In Sect. 4, the Nu!RehaVR system and the two implemented applications are presented. Section 5 describes the proposed approach to the clinical validation of the system. In Sect. 6, some conclusions are drawn.

The existing research

The development of telecommunication technologies enables the tele-rehabilitation as a reliable system to provide a series of rehabilitation-related services. One of the first uses of tele-technologies in rehabilitation has been the evaluation of the outcome of rehabilitation programmes (Russell et al. 2002) or the assessment of the needs of the patient (Ricker et al. 2002; Robinson et al. 2003; Sanford et al. 2006; Sanford et al. 2004). Tele-rehabilitation may be useful in improving communication and access to health care over distance (Torsney 2003; Hauber and Jones 2002), offering the possibility of early diagnosis and start of therapy in acute conditions. Furthermore, tele-rehabilitation allows the continuous monitoring of people at risk cutting costs and time and it plays a crucial role in shortening length of stay in hospital or specialised rehabilitation centres.

A tele-rehabilitation approach to promote the recovery of upper limb impairment after stroke with a system including a Web-based library of status tests, therapy games, and progress charts, which can be used with a variety of input devices, including a low-cost force-feedback joystick capable of assisting or resisting in movement has been applied (Holden 2005; Reinkensmeyer et al. 2002). Virtual reality techniques and high-speed networks create an environment allowing clinicians and technical staff at different sites to interact in a virtual reality environment (Rizzo et al. 2004).

Virtual reality with haptic interfaces and networked PCs has been applied in orthopaedic rehabilitation with the Rutgers & Stanford system for rehabilitation of hand, elbow, knee and ankle impairments to provide exercises while being monitored remotely by the therapists (Burdea et al. 2000). Preliminary results indicated that the system works well as a diagnostic tool and that the subjective evaluation by patients was very positive.

A Cyber-Glove and Rutgers Master U-ND force feedback glove, allowing user-interaction with a virtual environment has been used in stroke rehabilitation. A pilot clinical trial using such system in three patients with chronic stroke showed improvement in most of the hand parameters over the course of the training. The patients with greater cognitive impairment required more trials to acquire the skills requested.

Also language processing appeared to be related to how effectively participants learned to use the virtual rehabilitation centre (Jack et al. 2001).

The cognitive rehabilitation is a potential field for developing tele-rehabilitation, specially using virtual reality. Speech therapy has also been provided in tele-rehabilitation. The main findings in a pilot study are that the approach is feasible and the protocols should be improved in future studies (Hill et al. 2006).

The upper limb motor rehabilitation is one of the main fields of application in patients with stroke using gloves (Placid 2007), facilitating systems and virtual reality.

A virtual reality system based on the 3D motion tracking system Polhemus 3Space FastTrack to capture the patients arm movements by a magnetic receiver and to transmit it to the computer screen has been developed. The receiver is attached to a real object (end effector) grasped by the patient, or to a glove, worn by the subject (Iron et al. 2001).

One of the main issues in rehabilitation of impairments is due to acquired brain injury (ABI) and stroke is the recovery of executive functions, the capacity to carry out complex tasks in daily life. In fact, especially in ABI, the capacity of the orientation and the performance of the sequential tasks are impaired due to the frontal lesion. With a remote workstation, it is possible to create a sequence of virtual exercises and supervise the patient’s execution of them. The virtual tasks consisted mainly of simple movements which simulate activities of daily life, i.e. pouring water from a glass, using the hammer, posting an envelope into a mailbox slot, circumnavigating a donut, etc. The complexity of the task is determined by the therapist, according to a patient’s motor impairment and the degree of motor recovery.

The patient moves the real object (envelope, carafe, hammer) in a virtual environment and views on the computer screen the trajectory of the corresponding virtual object. During the performance, the patient can visualise in real time not only her/his movements but also the correct trajectory that he/she has to execute with the end effectors, to meet constraints given for the exercise, predetermined by the therapist.

With these systems, a pilot study in 5 stroke patients has been carried out. Subjects underwent the tele-rehabilitation program for 4 weeks. The therapy significantly improved the Fugl-Meyer mean score, the mean duration and the velocity of the movements, but not the Functional Independence Measure scale score (Iron et al. 2004).

H-CAD (Home Care Activity Desk) is an activity desk designed for the rehabilitation of the upper limb. This project deals with the development of a system capable of enabling patients affected by multiple sclerosis, stroke or traumatic brain injury to perform rehabilitation treatment for the upper limb at home. The system has been designed to allow patients to perform exercises at home, monitoring from the hospital the execution of these exercises, allowing the patient and the therapist to interact through a teleconference system. The feedback mechanism and the parameter measurements have two purposes. One is to immediately inform the user about the performance of a specific task. The other is to allow the therapist in the hospital setting to check how many attempts have been made to perform a certain task and how many of these attempts have resulted in successful task completion. During the hospital experiment, it emerged that the H-CAD system was accepted very well and generated a good general opinion. The worst scored characteristic of the H-CAD system was its aesthetic aspect.

The pilot study Nine Hole Peg Test values show an improving trend from baseline to the end of home test. The trial length does not allow us to know whether part of the improvement is sustained in time or whether motor function returns to baseline. A further validation phase increasing home test length should be carried out.

A development of the H-CAD system is the Hellodoc project. This project deals with the key activities to be implemented in order to validate the market in relation to the settlement of a home care–based service capable of extending the rehabilitation treatment of patients affected by neurological diseases like TBI, stroke or MS at home under the control and supervision of the hospital.

The effectiveness of tele-rehabilitation and virtual reality approach

Tele-rehabilitation is quite a recent field of research. These applications have mainly been developed as experimental trials for the implementation of next and future services. In the case of occupational therapy for neurological impairments (like TBI and stroke), the main advantages that can be envisaged consist in:

  • the chance to supervise exercises retrieving objective values of performance;

  • the ability of the patient in self-management at home of a set of exercises;

  • distance execution of exercises without the need to travel to the hospital site, addressing economic and social values.

The analysis of the first experimental studies started a few years ago; we review 9 studies to analyse the evidence of the effectiveness of tele-rehabilitation. Unfortunately, the studies included a small number of patients and the design is limited since only 2 studies were randomised. One study was case–control and the others were observational with or without intervention. The first study analysed is a telemonitoring study to support frail elderly people compared to a control group with the same health problems and same age. The effect seems relevant in terms of function which improved in the intervention group (Humbler et al. 2004).

Another observational study without specific intervention and telemonitoring emphasises the reliability of remote evaluation of pressure sores aimed at indicating the strategy of treatment. The data confirm the good reliability of this approach (Printable et al. 2004).

The upper limb rehabilitation of stroke patients with virtual reality can be used locally to introduce new exercises and, when applied remotely, seems to be effective in improving the impairment without affecting the function. The study is observational non-randomised and without a group of control; therefore, this promising data should be confirmed with a larger trial (Iron et al. 2004). Similar results with paradigms analogous to virtual reality have been obtained (Holden et al. 2007).

Some studies have already shown that virtual reality should be useful for the recovery of motor activity. A virtual environment allows the creation of a personalised exercise plan with specific tasks that are not possible to realise with a real instrument. Virtual reality also permits the development of complex sequences of exercises improving the capacity of planning a series of actions.

The remote intervention has been demonstrated to be at least as effective as the specific intervention of a therapist in the home setting (Sanford et al. 2006; Sanford et al. 2004). Similar effects have been found with different protocols of exercises in other studies (Carey et al. 2007; Page and Levine 2007). Using a haptic glove, the recovery after hand surgery seems to be facilitated (Heuser et al. 2007). From the analysis of the studies, we can conclude that there is not strong evidence about the efficacy of tele-rehabilitation due to the small size of the samples studied and the poor study designs. However, tele-rehabilitation is a promising approach and the data show a trend towards a positive effect of this approach.

The impact of a tele-rehabilitation service has to be considered also including patient satisfaction, continuity of care at home, exercise recordings, new competences of therapists and medical doctors.

A promising approach of virtual reality techniques into the rehabilitation of neurological diseases has been carried out by the NeuroVR project (Riva 2005; Riva et al. 2007), which released an easy to use and open source environment for therapists and patients to build rehabilitation experiments for patients affected by neurological diseases.

The Nu!Reha system

The experimental paradigm of the Nu!Reha desk has been the use of the technological features with the facilitation of the motor recovery. In fact, according to the most recent studies, the motor actions are facilitated by a significant contextual environment. Based on these observations in rehabilitation, a task-based therapy approach has been developed. It is based on the usage of a purposely conceived “activity desk” for the execution of occupation therapy tasks and exercises, allowing different grasping actions and interactions with sensorised objects. The device, shown in Fig. 1 in the complete installation is composed of a base unit and a list of components which have different functionality and scope of utilisation as they are connected to the base unit. At present, no components functionality is possible in absence of the base unit. The Nu!Reha components are:

  • base unit: the desk supporting the core structure of the system (both hardware and software). It is intended as the basic module of all the system: all other modules or subsystems are to be connected to this unit;

  • control pad: it allows the control of the system interface by part of the care-giver assisting the patient during the exercises;

  • shelf: shelf-like tool useful for the execution of vertical displacement–based exercises, they are equipped with an array of IR proximity sensors allowing detection of the presence of a sensorised object (an object covered by the reflective labels);

  • keyboard: module for the execution of exercises consisting in inputting a sequence of numbers with a phone/POS like keyboard;

  • RF tool: a plastic cylinder containing an internal electronic allowing its horizontal localisation;

  • video cameras and supports: two webcams with articulated stands are supplied for the video recording of the exercises performed by the patient;

  • accessories: a list of accessories are supplied in order to keep simple and feasible the system usage; they include a sensorised pen, plastic jars and cups, a book-alike reproduction, foam cubes.

By means of accessories and sensors, a number of different exercises can be configured directly by the therapist allowing a full customisable environment to perform different grasp/grip actions and upper limb movements: writing and pre-graphismFootnote 1 exercises, vertical and horizontal object displacements can be performed and monitored by the system.

The system is based on a sensorised LCD surface placed in front of the patient and acting as interface and working area for the execution of exercises. An SBC (Single Board Computer) placed inside the table supports the execution of all tasks and acquisitions requested by each exercise. A WiFi PCMCIA interface allows the connection to external LAN or ADSL connections for data uploading and configuration retrieving from an external server.

A typical exercise includes the utilisation of one or more sensorised accessories for the execution of contextual activities as they are provided by occupational therapy. For example, an exercise typology include the interaction with the sensorised pen (similar in weight and dimension to a normal pen) on the plastic surface upon the screen, as shown in Fig. 2, to perform a “writing” exercise (based on the writing performance) and/or “pre-graphism” exercise (based on trajectories defined by the therapist). Another exercise typology utilises a plastic jar with inside the RF tool: it is localised on the sensorised area allowing monitoring horizontal displacement through the positions suggested by the exercise (Zampolini et al. 2008). The patient has to locate the targets on the screen and she/he has to perform the related action, grasping and moving the jar up to these targets. The sequence can be defined by the therapist through a customisable set of instructions available at the beginning of each exercise.

The Nu!Reha system is the product of the Hellodoc and Hcad projects which investigated the implementation of a tele-rehabilitation concept applied to the rehabilitation of neurological impairments (Zampolini et al. 2007). The system has been validated through a single-case and randomised protocol that involves about 90 patients (Huygens and 2008). It has been validated with TBI, stroke and MS patients by three clinical groups located in Spain (Guttmann Institute -Barcelona), Belgium (MS National Centre—Melsbroek) and Italy (UORINFootnote 2 Trevi Hospital—Perugia).

The tele-rehabilitation service based on Nu!Reha platform is managed by means of 3 software applications:

  • configuration manager

  • exercise manager

  • data analysis manager

The configuration manager is a hospital-side application allowing to choose the type and number of exercises, and to assemble them in an execution sequence. The patient would be asked to execute the proposed exercise following the sequence list defined by the therapist during the configuration. The exercise manager is the application which is physically embedded into the portable unit at patient home. It is connected to the configuration manager, from which it downloads the configuration files. This application enables the following functions:

  • user interface, controlled by means of 4 keys (control pad)

  • exercise management, to define the list and the configuration options for each exercise

  • data recording, to record the camera views and data coming from sensors embedded in the portable unit

  • data encryptingandtransmitting to exchange info with the server.

The data analysis module processes the data available in the server unit. It is a hospital-side application giving the possibility to control and revise the information coming from the portable unit located at patient home. For each exercise the following information are saved: execution (date and time), number of repetitions, overall duration, sensor data (delay from exercise start, id of activated sensor). All data can be analysed by means of a kind of synoptic display, syncing them with the camera recording, allowing revising the patient posture and scenario.

Nu!RehaVR

In the present paper, we propose an environment based on X3DFootnote 3 and AjaX3DFootnote 4 technologies, called Nu!RehaVR, to improve significantly the features of the present Nu!Reha system, by means of a virtual reality environment where the patient could integrate the practice made on Nu!Reha desk. Nu!RehaVR increases the potentiality of Nu!Reha desk making available to the patient:

  • exercises in 3D scenarios, reproducing real-life situations which cannot be experienced directly by the patient alone in a safe and controlled way (as crossing a road), anticipating real-life involvement of the patient and its contextual factors;

  • exercises in 3D environments proposing differentiated set of objects which cannot be easily proposed “in vivo”, lacking the variety, typologies and different shapes in realisation (i.e. the chance to choose among a number of objects with the same function such as clocks.)

  • exercises simulating real-life tasks in a controlled manner, for instance allowing trimming the colour contrast, number of contextual and not-contextual stimula, delaying environment reaction and customising feedback channels.

The virtual environment is implemented in X3D, an ISO standard devoted to the realisation of virtual worlds on the Web. X3D is a powerful language that make it possible to interact with the user through various types of sensors. The Scene Access Interface (SAI) makes it possible to control and monitor the user behaviour using Script programs (usually written in Java or Javascript).

In the present case, we use Java to implement several Script nodes that perform the data management, control and assessment of the patient actions. The results of the assessment are passed to the Nu!Reha system via an XML file, to enable the clinician to interpret the results and monitor the patient’s activity.

The environment is implemented as a Web application based on open standards. In the Nu!Reha desk, a local copy of the main Web application and data are maintained to enable the desk to work even if the connection to the main centre is temporary lost.

The Nu!RehaVR system can be used by means of the sensorised LCD of the Nu!Reha desk, the keyboard and the sensorised pen. The system has also been designed to be used with immersive devices, like those we used: the 5DT digital gloves,Footnote 5 the Polhemus FastTrackFootnote 6 Motion Trackers and a 5DT HMD 800-26 Head Mounted Display.Footnote 7 Nu!RehaVR uses the X3D player Vivaty (formerly Flux).Footnote 8

We also used X3D for training and visual help on the Nu!Reha desk. In fact, a virtual world (Zampolini et al. 2008) has been implemented to show how to assemble the Nu!Reha system (for the therapist) and which features are available to the user. The therapist can use the virtual world to show to the patient how the various exercises available in the Nu!Reha system should be executed: several sensors and animations are able to show to the patient the correct sequence of actions to be performed and the expected behaviour to be obtained.

We designed and implemented two pilot exercises, related to outdoor scenarios and intrinsically risky for the target patients. The aims of the proposed exercise are:

  • to make available to patients a virtual reality environment for tele-rehabilitation; this environment will allow to train people in virtual worlds presenting some real situations where the patient is not able to act (being unable to move or because the context is not safe for her/him);

  • to propose new types of exercise compared to those available on the Nu!Reha desk to stimulate cognitive rehabilitation and the execution of complex tasks.

  • to assess the ability of the patient in performing elementary tasks using the tele-rehabilitation modality.

  • to extend interaction capabilities of the Nu!Reha desk by means of the virtual reality. The desk has been represented in a virtual world and the available functions have been described using animations and case studies in order to facilitate the proper assemblage of the Nu!Reha desk by the therapist and the successful usage by the patient.

The first exercise is related to the basic operations necessary to reach a given floor using an elevator. It is based on the error-free learning and on-line feedback approaches (Wilson and Evans 1996; Nakanishi and Schaal 2004): the patient is guided to the relevant position in the space as soon as she/he enters the right answer and she/he receives on the screen some messages explaining what happened as a consequence of her/his action.

The second exercise is related to the action of “crossing a road using a traffic light”. In this case, the actions to be performed are more complex than in the previous exercise: the patient has to press a button to express the intention of crossing the road, wait for the green light, check in both directions of the road if the cars stopped when their light became red, finally cross the road. The scenario is richer than that related to the first exercise, and the scene can be personalised with images the patient is familiar with (like photographs, scanned images, documents, etc.). This feature is really important and specific of virtual reality, in fact the therapists are able to customise the context of the exercise with pictures and objects familiar to the patient, increasing her/his feeling and generating more effective neurological stimula to the patient.

The idea comes from the need to complete in the cognitive framework the application of the same tele-rehabilitation apparatus: this chance brings advantages not only on the economical basis (the same system can be exploited a large number of exercises), but also in sense of flexibility and rehabilitative usefulness. In fact, the possibility to have complex tasks to train neurological patients facilitates the recovery of executive functions, attentional deficits and working memory. Furthermore, this practice is safe for the patient avoiding the risk related to the same activity applied in the real world where these deficits could lead to risk of accident.

The virtual world lets us include in the exercise set some cognitive practices which can be mixed in the exercise session proposed to the patient. It means that with the utilisation of such familiar interfaces (already utilised for contextual tasks), a patient can complete her/his rehabilitation therapy including some exercises based on:

  • problem solving;

  • planning activities;

  • categorisations;

  • attention training.

The opportunity of integrating the set of rehabilitation exercises with some practice made in a virtual world environment opens new scenarios for the rehabilitation of patients. In particular, the proposed practice may explore some interesting aspects:

  1. (a)

    stimulate the patient in dangerous situations where it would not be feasible to perform a real test (too dangerous for the patient or for other people; i.e.: driving a car, utilising an elevator if the patient is no able to walk, etc.);

  2. (b)

    stimulate the patient to carry out ordinary functions (i.e.: crossing a road) when the patient is forced to stay in bed;

  3. (c)

    develop some abilities using games or introducing tests at different levels: the patient should be able to perform a given sequence of actions in order to pass to the next level;

  4. (d)

    the progresses made by the patient performing the actions in the virtual worlds could be assessed and monitored by the system.

The proposed Nu!RehaVR system is also useful for training patients performing common actions in the virtual environment. The integration with the Nu!Reha desk occurs through an XML file that reports all the information related to the execution of the test, the actions made, the options selected and the (optional) score achieved during the test.

The Nu!RehaVR architecture

The Nu!RehaVR system has been implemented as three separate environments: the Administration (Fig. 3 shows that of the “crossing the road using a traffic light” exercise), reserved to the medical doctor to define and customise the exercises for the patients according to their level and type of disability; the Back Office to be accessed by the therapist to select the proper exercise among the available set, and the Front Office, to be used by the patient to access the virtual world related to the exercise chosen by the therapist. In Fig. 4 is shown the Front Office environment related to the “crossing a road using a traffic light” exercise, while in Fig. 5 is shown that related to the exercise “utilising an elevator to reach a given floor”. Fig. 6 summarises the architecture of Nu!RehaVR system.

For a given exercise, the customisation allowed in the Administration environment is related to the complexity of the scene, the relative complexity of the action to be performed, the colours and the texture used, and some features of the virtual world designed for being accessed by patients with different types of disability.

In the Back Office environment, the therapist will be able to select on a daily basis, the most appropriate exercise for the patient among a series of exercises defined by the medical doctor in the rehabilitation centre, following an analogous protocol as in the case of the “real” exercises made on the Nu!Reha desk.

At the end of the exercise, using a file coded in XML, Nu!RehaVR sends the output to the medical doctor at the Rehabilitation centre for the final data analysis. The final data analysis assembles all the information obtained both from the Nu!Reha desk and the Nu!RehaVR systems.

The Nu!RehaVR applications

The two applications implemented represent the precursor of a class of applications designed to perform a planning exercise related to outdoor situations: “utilising an elevator to reach a given floor” (named also “exercise 1”) and “crossing a road using a traffic light” (named also “exercise 2”).

The exercise 1 allows the patient to explore the scene by means of the pen interface on the screen and to choose the correct sequence of actions to perform the expected task. The application is targeted at a medium difficulty level reducing the number and typologies of components/signals outside of those strictly needed for the task itself: the scenario decoding and interactions are simplified and easy to understand. The proposed exercise requires the patient to plan and execute the following sequence:

  1. (a)

    to recognise the elevator;

  2. (b)

    to identify call button;

  3. (c)

    to activate call button;

  4. (d)

    to await for doors open;

  5. (e)

    to enter into the elevator cabin;

  6. (f)

    to identify the button panel;

  7. (g)

    to activate the correct button (defined by the therapist customising the exercise);

  8. (h)

    to await for door opening and exit.

This application includes feedback features which can optionally be configured by the therapist himself: positive feedback (outlining the success in each action of the sequence), negative feedback, general feedback for the sequence completion.

The exercise 2 is related to the more complex action of crossing a road using a traffic light. In this case, not only a more complex virtual scene than in exercise 1 is reached, but also the series of actions and controls the patient has to perform in the right sequence are more complex.

The scene is composed by a road, a pedestrian crossing, a traffic light close to the pedestrian crossing and some vehicles moving along the road. The vehicles motion is driven by an algorithm that handles the various situations: slowing down the movement reaching the traffic light with a red light, slowing down if the vehicle is moving faster than the preceding one, starting up the movement when the lights become green, etc.

The movement of the vehicles is generated so that each vehicle has assigned a randomly selected cruise speed, so that the patient will not be easily accustomed to their change in positions in the scene. On the opposite side of the road in the Administration environment, the therapists can use or upload an image with a special meaning for the patient, to make her/him more comfortable with the exercise environment and to increase her/his motivation with the tele-rehabilitation exercise.

The patient has to press a button to call the red light on the traffic light. Once the light is red, she/he has to check the right and left sides of the road and verify that the vehicles have stopped. If she/he tries to cross the road, selecting the red arrow, without having first pressed the button to call the stop signal, or without having checked the two directions of the cross, a sound will be heard and an error message will appear on the scene to inform her/him about the wrong action and reminding the correct sequence of operations. The details of the wrong action are also recorded to the output file to be passed to the Data Analysis.

If the patient performs the right sequence of operations, a sound of approval will be heard and a confirmation message will appear on the scene.

The output of the exercise, containing the most relevant information related to the patient action is saved on an XML file to be passed to the Nu!Reha system and to the rehabilitation centre for the Data Analysis. As a result, the medical doctor will be able to refine and optimise the future exercises of the patient.

Clinical validation

A first preliminary validation of the proposed approach is planned including a small number of patients, in a second stage we are planning to perform a Randomised Controlled Trial (RCT) including a larger population. Specific inclusion and exclusion criteria are defined in the following paragraphs. The inclusion criteria will have to be narrowed and only a sub-group of a specific pathology will be included in this study involving stroke and TBI patients.

With reference to inclusion criteria, the subjects are eligible for recruiting if they meet the following criteria: “age > 18”, established diagnosis of the specific pathological condition stroke or TBI; “Nine Hole Peg Test” (validated clinical test for the evaluation of hand mobility) performed in more than 25 s, ability to move at least one “Peg” in 180 s during the Nine Hole Peg Test, sufficient autonomous functioning, clinical status stable. Exclusion criteria are: disturbed upper limb function not related to TBI or stroke, serious cognitive and/or behavioural problems, serious emotional problems; major visual problems, communication problems, medical complications.

A single case study paradigm will be applied comparing the period of treatment, with one of the normal exercises. The exercise parameters (such as speed of execution, number and type of different stimula, required level of coordination and reaction times, etc.) will be customised on the basis of the specific patient conditions, as they are detected applying inclusion criteria clinical tests.

Different scales will be used to assess the improvement of: cognitive conditions after treatment, the feasibility of the system and the satisfaction of the patient.

Medical staff of UORIN in Trevi (Perugia, Italy) is planning to start soon the experimental protocol expecting first results for the middle of next year.

Conclusions

This work demonstrates the possibility of applying the X3D technology in the field of newly developed solutions for neurological tele-rehabilitation. The virtual reality applied in rehabilitation is considered to be a promising approach to enhance the possibility to perform a large set of exercises aimed at the recovery of the neurological disease. The idea is to exploit the advantage of virtual reality in representing to the patient her/his contextual factors, grouping in this term all the stimula which make up patient personal environment and actual life, such as her/his work tools, images of her/his home, relatives, which help facilitate an effective involvement of the person in the exercise execution.

The originality of this work has been the introduction of the planning of a series of actions that have a peculiar value to the series of exercises. This kind of approach is very important in the case of cognitive impairment (particularly the frontal lobe) and motor impairment.

First clinical approach of the Nu!RehaVR has been favoured by its implementation as an extension of the Nu!Reha system (already known by the medical staff). The chance to extend the treatment including virtual reality exercises is well considered as the application is easy to understand and customisable on basis of patient needs. Even if limited to two exercises, we were encouraged to proceed to a preliminary clinical validation phase (single case validation), which will take place from the beginning of August (recruiting phase). What is expected are clear indications about next developments of this approach:

  • the usability and acceptance of the system by part of therapist (configuration, administration) and patient (execution of exercise);

  • the clinical effectiveness, with reference to inclusion criteria and patient condition (age, type and severity of impairment, cultural level, motivation, etc.);

  • the possibility to configure a “mixed” exercise programme based on occupational therapy (Nu!Reha desk exercises) and virtual reality exercises.

Nevertheless, some predictor factors about feasibility and sustainability of this approach have been envisaged. They are referred both to the technical approach as well as to strategical issues. On the technical side:

  • referring to the effectiveness of neurological rehabilitation, the proposal of real life 3D problems is preferred (instead of proposing just a 3D navigation in different environments), the chance to execute an ordered list of tasks mimics outdoor real life situations;

  • the chance to configure real 3D views simplified in textures and details is strongly advised by the medical community, considering the actual cognitive ability (in decoding the proposed scenario) of each patient and its evolution;

  • the same concept of therapy imposes an “evolutionary” approach to the application developed: each exercise should be conceived in a modular way as it is referred to the cognitive complexity, accompanying patient in her/his recovery.

On the clinical side, some considerations could be advanced about the chance to propose these applications as a routine approach in rehabilitation/tele-rehabilitation therapies:

  • the role of operators (therapists, medical doctors responsible for the rehabilitation programs) is changing rapidly, a tele-rehabilitative service implies a number of different skills to be able to exploit the technological features offered, recognising the need to propose new applications and education jointly as part of a process aimed to develop a different way to interpret the rehabilitation itself and therefore new processes to make it possible;

  • the integration of this X3D application in an already available tele-rehabilitation product demonstrates the chance to mix contextual and virtual exercises proposing therapy at home in an effective way; hence, at the prototype stage the application should be tested with patients in tele-rehabilitation setting.

In conclusion, this system is a promising tool to be used in a rehabilitation centre and in tele-rehabilitation practice to integrate with the usual rehabilitation activity. A series of clinical studies are necessary to demonstrate its efficacy to facilitate functional recovery in different conditions.
